'''Intelligence and personality''' have some common features; for example, they both follow a relatively stable pattern throughout the whole of an individual’s life, which is genetically determined in different degrees.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Caspi |first=A. |title=The child is father of the man: personality continuities from childhood to adulthood |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology |volume=78 |issue=1 |date=2000|pages=158–172 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.78.1.158}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Deary |first1= I. J. |last2=Whalley |first2= L. J.|last3=Lemmon |first3= H. |last4=Crawford |first4= J. R. |last5= Starr |first5= J. M. |date=2000 |title=The stability of individual differences in mental ability from childhood to old age: follow-up of the 1932 Scottish Mental Survey|journal=Intelligence |volume=28|issue=1|pages=49–55 |doi=10.1016/s0160-2896(99)00031-8}}</ref> In addition, they are both significant predictors of various outcomes, such as educational achievement, occupational performance, and health.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Barrick |first1=M. R. |last2= Mount |first2= M. K. |date= 1991 |title= The Big Five personality dimensions and job performance: A meta - analysis |journal= Personnel Psychology |volume=44 |pages=1–26 |doi=10.1111/j.1744-6570.1991.tb00688.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Calvin |first1= C. |last2= Batty|first2=G. D. |last3=Deary |first3=I. J. |date= 2011|title= Cognitive epidemiology: Concepts, evidence, and future directions. |publisher=Oxford:Wiley–Blackwell}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kern|first1=M.|last2=Friedman,|first2=H.|date=2011|title=Personality and health|publisher=Oxford:Wiley–Blackwell}}</ref><ref name=" Poropat2009">{{cite journal|last1=Poropat |first1= A. |date=2009|title=A meta-analysis of the five-factor model of personality and academic performance|journal=Psychological Bulletin |volume=135|pages=322–338 |doi=10.1037/a0014996}}</ref> However, the traditional view in psychology is that there is no meaningful relationship between personality and intelligence and they should be studied as separate entities.
Firstly, intelligence is considered to be a cognitive process, while personality is recognised as being non-cognitive, and this implies that there is a great distinction between personality and intelligence. However, other psychologists argue that the distinction between cognitive and non-cognitive is vague because almost all personality traits have cognitive attributes, although they are more obvious in some traits than in others. For example, neuroticism is a personality trait, but is also related to rumination and compulsive thinking about possible threats,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Nolan|first1=S. A. |last2= Roberts|first2= J. E.|last3= Gotlib|first3= I. H.|date= 1998|title= Neuroticism and ruminative response style as predictors of change in depressive symptomatology|journal=Cognitive Therapy and Research|volume=22|pages=445–455|doi=10.1023/a:1018769531641}}</ref> while agreeableness is associated with understanding and considering the mental state of others.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nettle|first1= D. |last2= Liddle |first2=B.|date=2008 |title=Agreeableness is related to social-cognitive, but not social-perceptual, theory of mind|journal=European Journal of Personality |volume= 22|pages= 323–335 |doi=10.1002/per.672}}</ref>
In addition, different methods are generally used to assess intelligence and personality. Intelligence is normally measured by means of ability tests, whereas personality is usually assessed by means of questionnaires. Furthermore, different typical measurements lead to another conceptual distinction, which is that intelligence is considered to indicate individuals’ ''maximal performance'', while personality is believed to reflect their ''typical behaviour''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cronbach|first1= L. J. |date= 1949|title=Essentials of psychological testing }}</ref> However, others argue that multiple methods can be used to assess intelligence and personality; for example, questionnaires that require to be rated by self, peers or observers can also be used to measure individuals’ mental ability, although these kinds of measurement may lack accuracy. Therefore, different typical methods cannot prove that the relationship between intelligence and personality is a meaningless one. In addition, since individuals’ ability can also affect their typical behaviour, IQ can predict outcomes related to aspects such as performance at work, academic achievement, and health.<ref>{{cite book|last1= Sternberg |first1=R. J.|last2= Grigorenko |first2= E. L.| title=The general factor of intelligence: How general is it? |pages= 331–380|location=Mahwah |publisher= NJ: Erlbaum}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gottfredson |first1=L. S. |last2=Deary|first2= I. J. |date= 2004|title=Intelligence predicts health and longevity, but why?|journal= Current Directions in Psychological Science|volume=13|pages=1–4 |doi=10.1111/j.0963-7214.2004.01301001.x}}</ref> Therefore, ability tests can provide indices of both maximal performance and typical behaviour.
An increasing number of studies have recently explored the relationship between intelligence and the Big Five personality traits.
==Openness/Intellect== [[Openness to experience|Openness]] shows the strongest positive relationship with ''g'' among the Big Five personality traits, ranging from r=.06 to r=.42.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= Ashton |first1=M. C. |last2= Lee. |first2= K.|last3=Vernon|first3=P. A.|last4=Jang|first4=K. L. |date= 2000 |title=Fluid intelligence, crystallized intelligence, and the Openness/Intellect factor.|journal=Journal of Research in Personality |volume=34|pages=197–207 |doi=10.1006/jrpe.1999.2276}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Austin|first1=E. J.|last2= Deary|first2= I. J.|last3=Gibson|first3=G. J. |date= 1997|title= Relationship between ability and personality: Three hypotheses tested. |journal=Intelligence|volume=25 |pages= 49–70 |doi=10.1016/s0160-2896(97)90007-6}}</ref><ref name="Austin2002">{{cite journal|last1=Austin= |first1=A. J.|last2= Deary |first2= I. J. |last3=Whiteman|first3= M. C. |last4=Fowkes|first4=F. G. R. |last5= Padersen|first5=N. L. |last6= Rabbitt, |first6=P.|last7=Bent |first7= N. |last8= McInnes |first8=L. |date= 2002|title= Relationships between ability and personality: Does intelligence contribute positively to personal and social adjustment? |journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=32|pages=1391–1411 |doi=10.1016/s0191-8869(01)00129-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Chamorro-Premuzic|first1= T. |last2=Furnham|first2=A. |date= 2008|title=Personality, intelligence and approaches to learning as predictors of academic performance.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=44 |pages=1596–1603 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2008.01.003}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= DeYoung|first1= C. G.|last2=Peterson|first2= J. B.|last3= Higgins|first3= D.M.|date= 2005 |title= Sources of Openness/Intellect: Cognitive and neuropsychological correlates of the fifth factor of personality. |journal=Journal of Personality|volume=73|pages= 825–858|doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.2005.00330.x|pmid=15958136}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Furnham|first1=A.|last2=Chamorro-Premuzic|first2=T.|date=2004|title=Personality, intelligence, and art.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=36|pages=705–715|doi=10.1016/s0191-8869(03)00128-4}}</ref> Individuals with a high level of openness enjoy the experience of learning and prefer an intellectually stimulating environment. Therefore, openness shows a significant moderate association with [[Fluid and crystallized intelligence|crystallized intelligence]] (r=.30), but a non-significant low association with [[Fluid and crystallized intelligence|fluid intelligence]] (r=.08),<ref name="Ackerman1997">{{cite journal|last1= Ackerman|first1=P. L. |last2= Heggestad|first2=E. D.|date= 1997|title= Intelligence, personality, and interests: Evidence for overlapping traits. |journal= Psychological Bulletin|volume=121|pages=219–245|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.121.2.219}}</ref> and these results are consistent with those of other studies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bates|first1=T. C.|last2=Shieles|first2=A.|date=2003 |title= Crystallized intelligence as a product of speed and drive for experience: The relationship of inspection time and openness to g and Gc. |journal=Intelligence |volume= 31|pages=275–287 |doi=10.1016/s0160-2896(02)00176-9}}</ref>
Some psychologists have recently pointed out that previous instruments used to measure openness actually assessed two distinctive aspects. The first is intellect, which reflects intellectual engagement and perceived intelligence and is marked by ideas, while the second is emotion, which reflects the artistic and contemplative qualities related to being engaged in sensation and perception and is marked by fantasy, aesthetics, feelings and actions.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= DeYoung|first1=C. G.|last2=Quilty |first2=L. C. |last3=Peterson|first3= J. B.|date=2007|title=Between facets and domains: 10 aspects of the Big Five. |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=93|pages= 880–896 |doi=10.1037/0022-3514.93.5.880 |pmid=17983306}}</ref> On this basis, intellect was found to be associated with the neural system of the working memory, which is related to ''g'', whereas openness was not.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=DeYoung|first1= C. G. |last2= Shamosh|first2= N. A.|last3=Green|first3=A. E.|last4= Braver|first4= T. S.|last5=Gray|first5=J. R.|date= 2009 |title=Intellect as distinct from Openness: Differences revealed by fMRI of working memory. |journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume= 97|pages=883–892 |doi=10.1037/a0016615 |pmid=19857008 |pmc=2805551}}</ref> In addition, according to a study of genetic behaviour, intellect is genetically closer to intelligence than openness.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wainwright|first1=M. A. |last2= Wright |first2= M. J. |last3=Luciano |first3=M.|last4=Geffen|first4=G. M. |last5= Martin |first5= N. G. |date= 2008|title= Genetic covariation among facets of openness to experience and general cognitive ability .|journal= Twin Research and Human Genetics|volume=11 |pages=275–286 |doi=10.1375/twin.11.3.275}}</ref>
==Conscientiousness== The association between [[conscientiousness]] and intelligence is complex and uncertain. Individuals with a lower level of intelligence are always assumed to tend to behave in an orderly fashion and do extra work, which is related to being conscientious, in order to compensate for their lower level of cognitive ability.<ref name="Chamorro-Premuzic2005">{{cite journal|last1= Chamorro-Premuzic|first1=T.|last2=Moutafi|first2=J.|last3=Furnham|first3=A.|date= 2005|title=The relationship between personality traits, subjectively-assessed and fluid intelligence.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=38|issue=7 |pages=1517–1528|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2004.09.018}}</ref> However, although intelligence has been observed to be negatively correlated with conscientiousness in some studies,<ref name=" Poropat2009"/><ref name="Chamorro-Premuzic2005"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moutafi|first1=J.|last2=Furnham|first2=A.|last3=Crump|first3=J.|date= 2003|title=Demographic and personality predictors of intelligence: A study using the NEO Personality Inventory and the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. |journal=European Journal of Personality|volume=17|pages=79–94|doi=10.1002/per.471}}</ref><ref name="Judge2007">{{cite journal|last1= Judge|first1=T. A.|last2=Jackson|first2=C. L.|last3=Shaw|first3= J. C.|last4=Scott |first4=B. A.|last5=Rich|first5=B. L. |date=2007 |title=Self-efficacy and work-related performance: the integral role of individual differences |journal=Journal of Applied Psychology|volume=92|issue=1 |pages=107–127 |doi=10.1037/0021-9010.92.1.107 |pmid=17227155}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Moutafi|first1=J.|last2=Furnham|first2=A.|last3=Crump|first3=J.|date= 2006|title= What facets of openness and conscientiousness predict fluid intelligence score? |journal=Learning and Individual Differences|volume=16 |pages=31–42|doi=10.1016/j.lindif.2005.06.003}}</ref> others have not found this correlation to be significant and have even found a positive relationship.<ref name="Austin2002"/><ref name="Ackerman1997"/>
Furthermore, some interaction has been found between conscientiousness and intelligence. Conscientiousness has been found to be a stronger predictor of safety behaviour in individuals with a low level of intelligence than in those with a high level.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Postlethwaite|first1= B.|last2= Robbins|first2=S.|last3= Rickerson|first3= J.|last4=McKinniss|first4= T.|date=2009|title= The moderation of conscientiousness by cognitive ability when predicting workplace safety behaviour.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume= 47 |pages= 711–716|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2009.06.008}}</ref> This interaction may also be found in educational and occupational settings in future studies. Therefore, relatively speaking, an increase in either conscientiousness or intelligence may compensate for a deficiency in the other.
==Extraversion== The results of a meta-analysis research conducted in 1997, which consisted of 35 studies, indicated that there is a very small, but statistically significant positive correlation between [[Extraversion and introversion|Extraversion]] and ''g'' (r=.08).<ref name="Ackerman1997"/> Another recent meta-analysis of extraversion, which comprised 50 new studies, reported a similar correlation (r=.05).<ref name="Wolf2005">{{cite journal|last1=Wolf|first1= M. B. |last2=Ackerman|first2=P. L.|date= 2005|title=Extraversion and intelligence: A meta-analytic investigation. |journal=Personality and Individual Differences |volume=39 |pages=531–542 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2005.02.020}}</ref>
There are some moderating variables in the relationship between extraversion and ''g'' including differences in the assessment instruments and samples’ age and sensory stimulation; for example, no meaningful correlation was found between extraversion and intelligence in the samples of children.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rawlings |first1=D. |last2=Skok|first2=M.|date=1993|title= Extraversion, venturesomeness and intelligence in children.|journal= Personality and Individual Differences|volume=15|pages=389–396|doi=10.1016/0191-8869(93)90066-c}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Saklofske|first1=D. H.|last2= Kostura|first2= D. D.|date=1990|title= Extraversion–introversion and intelligence.|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=11 |pages=547–551|doi=10.1016/0191-8869(90)90036-q}}</ref> Furthermore, Bates and Rock (2004) used [[Raven's Progressive Matrices|Raven’s matrices]] and found that extraverts performed better than introverts with increasing auditory stimulation,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bates|first1=T. C.|last2=Rock|first2=A.|date=2004|title=Personality and information processing speed: Independent influences on intelligent performance. |journal=Intelligence|volume=32|issue=1|pages=33–46|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2003.08.002}}</ref> whereas introverts performed best in silence. This result is consistent with that of Revelle et al. (1976).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Revelle|first1=W.|last2=Amaral|first2=P.|last3=Turriff |first3=S. |date= 1976|title= Introversion/extraversion, time stress, and caffeine|journal=Science |volume= 192 |pages= 149–150 |doi=10.1126/science.1257762}}</ref> In addition, different measures and different sub-traits of extraversion have been found to cause significantly different correlations.<ref name="Wolf2005"/>
==Neuroticism== [[Neuroticism]] has been found to have a reliable negative association with ''g''(r=-.33).<ref name="Ackerman1997"/> However, other researchers have recently reported a lower coefficient of .09 for general mental ability and emotional stability.<ref name="Judge2007"/> Although these studies have some differences, they all indicate that intelligence increases with a decrease in negative emotion.
One of the reasons for this negative correlation is [[Test anxiety]], which refers to the psychological distress experienced by individuals prior to, or during, an evaluative situation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zuckerman |first1=M. |last2=Spielberger |first2= C. D. |title=Emotions and anxiety: New concepts, methods, and applications |pages=57–81|publisher=New York:Wiley}}</ref> This is closely associated with neuroticism <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Chamorro - Premuzic|first1=T.|last2=Ahmetoglu|first2= G.|last3= Furnham |first3= A. |date= 2008|title= Little more than personality:Trait determinants of test anxiety . |journal=Learning and Individual Differences |volume=18 |pages= 258–263 |doi=10.1016/j.lindif.2007.09.002}}</ref> and has a negative influence on individuals’performance in an intelligence test (r=-.23).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wicherts|first1=J. M.|last2=Scholten|first2=A.|date=2010|title=Test anxiety and the validity of cognitive tests: A confirmatory factor analysis perspective and some empirical findings.|journal=Intelligence|volume=38 |pages=169–178|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2009.09.008}}</ref>
Some argue that all the aforementioned evidence indicates that neuroticism is related to test performance rather than true intelligence. However, according to the results of a longitudinal study recently conducted by Gow et al., (2005), neuroticism influences an age-related decline in intelligence and there is a small negative correlation between neuroticism and a change in the level of IQ (r=-.18).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gow|first1=A. J.|last2=Whiteman|first2= M. C.|last3=Pattie|first3= A.|last4= Deary |first4=I. J. |date=2005|title= The personality–intelligence interface: Insights from an ageing cohort. |journal= Personality and Individual Differences|volume=39|pages=751–761 |doi=10.1016/j.paid.2005.01.028}}</ref> Although it is still debatable if neuroticism reduces general intelligence, this study provided some valuable evidence and a direction for research. In addition, some interaction between intelligence and neuroticism has been found. Individuals with a high level of neuroticism demonstrated a poor performance, health, and adjustment only if they had a low level of intelligence.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leikas|first1=S.|last2=M¨akinen|first2=S.|last3=L¨ onnqvist|first3=J.E.|last4=Verkasalo|first4= M. |date=2009|title=Cognitive ability×Emotional stability interactions on adjustment.|journal=European Journal of Personality|volume=23|pages=329–342|doi=10.1002/per.711}}</ref> Therefore, intelligence may act as a buffer and compensate neuroticism in individuals.
==Agreeableness== No significant association between agreeableness and ''g'' has been found in previous research.<ref name="Ackerman1997"/><ref name="Judge2007"/> However, some components of agreeableness have been found to be related to intelligence. For example, aggression is negatively associated with intelligence (r is around -.20) <ref name="Ackerman1997"/><ref>{{cite journal|issue=|last1=DeYoung|first1=C. G.|last2=Peterson|first2= J. B.|last3=S´eguin, |first3= J. R.|last4=Pihl|first4=R. O.|last5=Tremblay|first5= R. E.|date= 2008|title=Externalizing behavior and the higher-order factors of the Big Five. |journal= Journal of Abnormal Psychology|volume= 117|pages=947–953|doi=10.1037/a0013742|pmid=19025240}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Séguin|first1=J. R.|last2=Boulerice|first2= B.|last3= Harden|first3=P. |last4= Tremblay|first4=R. E.|last5=Pihl|first5=R. O.|date= 1999 |title=Executive functions and physical aggression after controlling for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, general memory, and IQ. |journal= Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry|volume= 40|pages= 1197–1208 |doi=10.1111/1469-7610.00536}}</ref> because unintelligent people may experience more frustration, which may lead to aggression <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lynam|first1=D. R.|last2=Moffitt|first2=T. E. |last3= Stouthamer-Loeber|first3=M. |date= 1993|title= Explaining the relation between IQ and delinquency: Class, race, test motivation, school failure, or self-control? |journal= Journal of Abnormal Psychology|volume= 102|pages=187–196 |doi=10.1037/0021-843x.102.2.187}}</ref> and aggression and intelligence may share some biological factors.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=DeYoung|first1= C. G.|last2=Peterson|first2=J. B.|last3=Séguin|first3=J. R. |last4=Mejia|first4= J. M.|last5=Pihl|first5=R. O.|last6=Beitchman|first6=J. H.|last7=Jain|first7=U. |last8=Tremblay|first8=R. E.|last9=Kennedy|first9=J. L.|last10=Palmour|first10=R. M.|date=2006|title= The dopamine D4 receptor gene and moderation of the association between externalizing behavior and IQ.|journal=Archives of General Psychiatry|volume=63|pages=1410–1416|doi=10.1001/archpsyc.63.12.1410|pmid=17146015|pmc=3283582}}</ref> In addition, emotional perception and emotional facilitation, which are also components of agreeableness, have been found to be significantly correlated with intelligence.<ref>{{cite journal|last1= Mayer|first1=J. D.|last2=Salovey|first2= P.|last3= Caruso|first3= D. R. |date= 2004|title=Emotional intelligence: Theory, findings, and implications|journal=Psychological Inquiry |volume= 60 |pages=197–215 |doi=10.1207/s15327965pli1503_02}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1= Mayer|first1=J. D.|last2=Salovey |first2= P. |last3= Caruso |first3=D. R. |date= 2008|title= Emotional intelligence: New ability or eclectic traits? |journal=American Psychologist|volume=63|pages= 503–517 |doi=10.1037/0003-066x.63.6.503}}</ref> This may be because emotional perception and emotional facilitation are components of emotional intelligence and some researchers have found that emotional intelligence is a Second-Stratum Factor of ''g''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=MacCann|first1=C.|last2=Joseph|first2=D. L.|last3=Newman|first3= D. A.|last4=Roberts|first4=R. D.|date=2014|title= Emotional intelligence is a second-stratum factor of intelligence: Evidence from hierarchical and bifactor models.|journal=Emotion|volume=14|issue= 2|pages= 358–374|doi=10.1037/a0034755}}</ref>

revision.text:
'''Invisible support''' is a [[Psychology|psychological]] term used to describe a type of [[social support]] in which supportive exchanges are not visible to recipients. There are two possible situations that can describe acts of invisible support. The first possibility entails a situation where ''recipients are completely unaware of the supportive transaction between themselves and support-givers''.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Bolger, Zuckerman, & Kessler|first=|year=2000|title=Invisible Support and Adjustment to Stress|url=|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=79 |issue=6|pages=953–961|via=ProQuest|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.79.6.953|citeseerx=10.1.1.488.333}}</ref> For example, a spouse may choose to spontaneously take care of housework without mentioning it to the other couple-member. Invisible support also occurs when ''recipients are aware of an act that takes place but do not interpret the act as a supportive exchange''.<ref name=":0" /> In this case, a friend or family member may subtly provide advice in an indirect manner as a means to preserve the recipient's self-esteem or to defer his or her attention from a stressful situation. Invisible support can be viewed on both ends of an exchange, in which the recipient is unaware of the support received and the provider enacts support in a skillful, subtle way.
== Background == It is well known that perceptions of social support availability predict better adjustment to stressful life events.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=House, Landis, & Umberson|first=|year=1988|title=Social relationships and health|url=|journal=Science|volume=241 |issue=4865|pages=540–545|via=|doi=10.1126/science.3399889}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cohen|first=|year=1992|title=Stress, social support, and disorder|url=|journal=The Meaning and Measurement of Social Support|volume=|pages=109–124|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Close personal relationships and health outcomes: A key to the role of social support.|last=Gurung, R., Sarason, B., & Sarason, I|first=|publisher=Handbook of personal relationships: theory, research and interventions (2nd ed)|year=1997|isbn=|location=Chichester, UK|pages=547–73|quote=|via=Wiley}}</ref> It has been found that the perception of support availability is inherently comforting, and can serve as a psychological safety-net that motivates self-reliant [[Coping (psychology)|coping]] efforts in the face of [[Stress (psychology)|stress]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wethington, E., & Kessler, R. C.|first=|year=1986|title=Perceived support, received support, and adjustment to stressful life events|url=|journal=Journal of Health and Social Behavior|volume=27|issue=1|pages=78–89|via=|doi=10.2307/2136504|pmid=3711634|jstor=2136504}}</ref> Although the perception of support availability is associated with better adjustment, the knowledge that one has been the recipient of specific supportive acts has often been unhelpful to effectively reduce stress.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bolger, N., Foster, M., Vinokur, A. D., & Ng, R.|first=|year=1996|title=Close relationships and adjustments to a life crisis: The case of breast cancer|url=|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=70 |issue=2|pages=283–294|via=|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.70.2.283}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lieberman, M. A.|first=|year=1986|title=Social supports: The consequences of psychologizing: A commentary.|url=|journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology|volume=54 |issue=4|pages=461–465|via=|doi=10.1037/0022-006x.54.4.461}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Barrera Jr, M.|first=|year=1986|title=Distinctions between social support concepts, measures, and models|url=|journal=American Journal of Community Psychology|volume=14 |issue=4|pages=413–445|via=|doi=10.1007/bf00922627}}</ref> The knowledge of receiving help may come at a cost with decreased feelings of [[self-esteem]] and [[self-efficacy]], because it increases recipients' awareness towards their personal difficulties to manage stressors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fisher, J. D., Nadler, A., & Whitcher-Alagna, S.|first=|year=1982|title=Recipient reactions to aid|url=|journal=Psychological Bulletin|volume=91 |issue=1|pages=27–54|via=|doi=10.1037/0033-2909.91.1.27}}</ref> People's well-intentioned support attempts may also be miscarried, and their efforts could either fail or even worsen the situation for a person under stress.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Coyne, J. C., Wortman, C. B., & Lehman, D. R.|first=|year=1988|title=The other side of support: Emotional over-involvement and miscarried helping.|url=|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Since supportive acts benefit recipients but their actual knowledge of receiving support is sometimes harmful, it has been theorized that the most effective support exchange would involve one in which the provider reports giving support but the recipient does not notice that support has occurred. From a cost-benefit point of view, invisible support would be optimal for the recipient because the benefits of provision are accrued while the costs of receipt are avoided.<ref name=":0" /> Using the same idea, it also implies that the least effective type of support would be one in which the provider does not report providing support but the recipient reports receiving it.<ref name=":0" /> The first investigation of invisible support involved a couples study in which one member was preparing for the New York State Bar Exam. Support receipt and provision were measured by having both couple members complete daily diary entries. Over the course of one month, stressed individuals who reported low frequency of received support (but whose partner ranked his or her own actions as highly supportive) rated themselves low on anxiety and depression compared to other individuals who reported high frequency of received support.<ref name=":0" />
== Invisible support compared to visible support == A substantial body of work has evidence to suggest that support is most effective when it is invisible or goes unnoticed by recipients.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Howland, M., & Simpson, J. A.|first=|year=2010|title=Getting in under the radar a dyadic view of invisible support|doi=10.1177/0956797610388817|pmid=21097721|journal=Psychological Science|volume=21|issue=12|pages=1878–1885|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shrout, P. E., Herman, C. M., & Bolger, N.|first=|year=2006|title=The costs and benefits of practical and emotional support on adjustment: A daily diary study of couples experiencing acute stress|url=|journal=Personal Relationships|volume=13 |issue=1|pages=115–134|via=|doi=10.1111/j.1475-6811.2006.00108.x}}</ref> While invisible support has been shown to benefit recipients over visibly supportive acts in some cases, there have also been instances where recipients have benefitted from visible support as well. For example, greater observed support enacted by intimate partners during couples’ support-relevant exchanges have been shown to build feelings of closeness and support, boost positive mood and self-esteem, and foster greater goal achievement and relationship quality across time.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Collins, N. L., & Feeney, B. C.|first=|year=2004|title=Working models of attachment shape perceptions of social support: evidence from experimental and observational studies|url=|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=87 |issue=3|pages=363–383|via=|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.87.3.363|pmid=15382986}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sullivan, K. T., Pasch, L. A., Johnson, M. D., & Bradbury, T. N.|first=|year=2010|title=Social support, problem solving, and the longitudinal course of newlywed marriage|url=|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=98 |issue=4|pages=631–644|via=|doi=10.1037/a0017578|pmid=20307134}}</ref> It has been recently suggested that acts of invisible support and visible support may be beneficial or costly depending on different circumstances. To investigate this idea, a recent study in 2013 compared the short-term and long-term effects of visible and invisible support reception during romantic couples’ discussions of each partner’s personal goal.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Girme, Y. U., Overall, N. C., & Simpson, J. A.|first=|year=2013|title=When visibility matters: short-term versus long-term costs and benefits of visible and invisible support|doi=10.1177/0146167213497802|pmid=23885036|journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin|volume=39|issue=11|pages=1441–1454|via=}}</ref> It was found that either type of support was more beneficial depending on the emotional distress that recipients felt at the time. Visible emotional support (support through reassurance, encouragement, and understanding) was associated with perceptions of greater support and discussion success for recipients who felt greater distress during the discussion. In contrast, invisible emotional support was not associated with recipients’ post-discussion perceptions of support or discussion success. For long-term support effects, it was found that only invisible emotional support predicted greater goal achievement across the following year.<ref name=":1" /> When put together, these findings suggest that visible support and invisible support have unique functions for well-being. When people are under distress, visible support appears to be a short-term remedy to reassure recipients that they are cared for and supported. These benefits are only present when recipients are actually distressed during the time that the supportive act takes place. On the other hand, while invisible support tends to go unnoticed by recipients, it seems to play an integral role in the long-term success of goal-maintenance.<ref name=":1" />
== Effects on support providers == {{primary sources|section|date=November 2016}} {{see also|social support|Psychology|Stress (psychological)|Coping (psychology)|self-esteem|self-efficacy}} The effects of invisible support on recipients have been extensively investigated, but the consequences of invisible support on providers are less known. One study in 2016 investigated the benefits and costs of invisible support on couple-members who enacted supportive behaviors by differentiating the processes of invisible emotional support (support through reassurance, encouragement, and understanding) from processes of invisible instrumental support (providing tangible aid such as sending money or childcare).<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=König, C., Stadler, G., Knoll, N., Ochsner, S., Hornung, R., & Scholz, U.|first=|year=2016|title=Invisible Support: Effects on the Provider's Positive and Negative Affect|url=|journal=Applied Psychology: Health and Well-Being|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> No costs of support-giving were found for providers when they demonstrated acts of invisible emotional support. The effects for invisible instrumental support told a different story, where providers who reported high relationship satisfaction were unaffected, but providers who reported low relationship satisfaction were negatively affected by their acts of invisible instrumental support with an increase in negative mood.<ref name=":2" /> These findings suggest that emotional comfort may be a more central function to maintain close relationships than instrumental support. Therefore, providing invisible emotional support may lead to less perceptions of a costly inequity than providing invisible instrumental support on average. However, since invisible instrumental support did not incur costs for providers who reported high relationship satisfaction, it implies that high relationship satisfaction may buffer potential costs that would otherwise be felt by support-providers.<ref name=":2" /> The differential results between invisible instrumental and emotional support indicate that a solid distinction between instrumental and emotional social support may be useful to take into account when investigating effects of invisible support as a whole.<ref name=":2" />

{{ Infobox Buddhist term | title = Karuṇā | en = Compassion | pi = karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā | sa = karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā (करुणा) | bn = করুণা
(kôruna) | my = ကရုဏာ | my-Latn = ɡəjṵnà | zh = 悲 | zh-Latn = cíbēi | ja = 慈悲 | ja-Latn = jihi | km = ករុណា
(Karuna) | ko = 자비 | ko-Latn = | lo = | mnw = | mnw-Latn = | shn = | shn-Latn = | si = | si-Latn = | ta = கருணை
(Karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ai) | th = กรุณา | bo = སྙིངརྗེ | bo-Latn = | vi = bi | id = }} {{Buddhism|terse=1}} '''''Karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā''''' (in both [[Sanskrit]] and [[Pali]]) is generally translated as [[compassion]].Regarding the Sanskrit word, see Monier-Williams (1899), p. 255, entry for "karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā" (retrieved at http://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/MWScan/MWScanpdf/mw0255-karaTa.pdf), where the noun form of the word is defined as "pity, compassion". For the Pali word, see Rhys, Davids & Stede (1921–25), p. 197, entry for "Karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā" (retrieved at http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.1:1:356.pali{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}), where it is defined as "pity, compassion". In general, contemporary scholars, translators and interpreters have consistently translated the word as "compassion," not "pity." This can be seen, for instance, in (listed chronologically) [[A. K. Warder|Warder]] (1970/2004, p. 95), [[Nanamoli Bhikkhu|Ñāṇamoli]] (Buddhaghosa & Ñāṇamoli, 1975/1991, [[Visuddhimagga|Vsm.]] IX.77ff., pp. 306ff.), [[Hammalawa Saddhatissa|Saddhatissa]] (1985/1994, p. 3, [[Sutta Nipata|Sn]] 3.39), [[Thanissaro Bhikkhu|Thanissaro]] (1994, [[Anguttara Nikaya|AN]] 3.65), [[Sharon Salzberg|Salzberg]] (1995, pp. 102ff.), [[Rupert Gethin|Gethin]] (1998, p. 187), and [[Bhikkhu Bodhi|Bodhi]] (2000, [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 41.7, p. 1325). It is part of the spiritual path of both [[Buddhism]] and [[Jainism]]. ==Buddhism== Karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is important in all schools of Buddhism. For [[Theravāda]] Buddhists, dwelling in karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is a means for attaining a happy present life and heavenly rebirth. For [[Mahāyāna]] Buddhists, karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is a co-requisite for becoming a [[Bodhisattva]]. ===Theravada Buddhism=== In Theravāda Buddhism, karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is one of the four "divine abodes" (''[[Brahmavihara|brahmavihāra]]''), along with loving kindness ([[Pāli]]: ''[[mettā]]''), sympathetic joy (''[[mudita]]'') and equanimity (''[[upekkha]]'').Gethin (1998), pp.186-187; and, Rhys Davids & Stede, [https://archive.is/20120711002204/http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.1:1:356.pali ''op. cit.''] In the [[Pali canon]], the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] recommends cultivating these four virtuous mental states to both [[householder (Buddhism)|householders]] and [[bhikkhu|monastics]].For instance, in the ''Kālāmā Sutta'' ([[Anguttara Nikaya|AN]] 3.65), the Buddha speaks of all Noble Disciples (''ariya-[[savaka]]'') developing the brahmaviharas [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an03/an03.065.than.html (Thanissaro, 1994).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006181109/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an03/an03.065.than.html |date=2011-10-06 }} When one develops these four states, the Buddha counsels radiating them in all directions, as in the following stock canonical phrase regarding karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā: {{quote|He keeps pervading the first direction—as well as the second direction, the third, and the fourth—with an awareness imbued with compassion. Thus he keeps pervading above, below, & all around, everywhere & in every respect the all-encompassing cosmos with an awareness imbued with compassion: abundant, expansive, immeasurable, free from hostility, free from ill will.''Kālāmā Sutta'' ([[Anguttara Nikaya|AN]] 3.65), trans. [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an03/an03.065.than.html Thanissaro (1994).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006181109/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an03/an03.065.than.html |date=2011-10-06 }} The "four directions" refer to east, south, west and north.}} Such a practice purifies one's mind, avoids evil-induced consequences, leads to happiness in one's present life and, if there is a future [[Karma in Buddhism|karmic]] [[Rebirth (Buddhism)|rebirth]], it will be in a [[Buddhist cosmology|heavenly realm]].[[Anguttara Nikaya|AN]] 3.65 [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an03/an03.065.than.html (Thanissaro, 1994).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006181109/http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an03/an03.065.than.html |date=2011-10-06 }} In regards to in which heavenly realm a frequent karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā dweller will be reborn, [[Anguttara Nikaya|AN]] 4.125 [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/an/an04/an04.125.than.html (Thanissaro, 2006)] identifies it as the realm of radiant (''abhassara'') devas, whose lifespans last two eons. The [[atthakatha|Pali commentaries]] distinguish between karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā and [[mettā]] in the following complementary manner: Karuna is the desire to remove harm and suffering (''ahita-[[dukkha]]-apanaya-kāmatā'') from others; while mettā is the desire to bring about the well-being and happiness (''hita-[[sukha]]-upanaya-kāmatā'') of others.[[Sutta Nipata|Sn]]-[[Atthakatha|A]] 128 (cited by Rhys Davids & Stede, 1921–25, ''op. cit.''); see also, [http://www.buddhanet.net/e-learning/buddhism/bs-s15.htm BDEA & BuddhaNet (n.d.).] Similarly, the post-canonical [[Visuddhimagga]], chapter IX, vv. 105-109, provides further elucidation, such as with a metaphor describing ''mettā'' as a mother's wish for her (healthy) child to grow up and ''karuṇā'' as a mother's wish for her sick child to get well (Buddhaghosa & Nanamoli, 1975/99, pp. 313-4). The "far enemy" of karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is [[cruelty]], a mind-state in obvious opposition. The "near enemy" (quality which superficially resembles karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā but is in fact more subtly in opposition to it), is (sentimental) [[pity]]: here too one wants to remove suffering, but for a partly selfish (attached) reason hence not the pure motivation. [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/nanamoli/PathofPurification2011.pdf Buddhagosha, 'Vishudimagga'] Section 2.99http://www.insightmeditationcenter.org/books-articles/dhamma-lists/] {{Page needed|date=October 2018}} In the Pali Canon, buddhas are also described as choosing to teach "out of compassion for beings."In Pali, ''sattesu ... kāruññataṃ paṭicca'', found in [[Digha Nikaya|DN]] 3.6 (regarding [[Vipassī Buddha]]), [[Majjhima Nikaya|MN]] 26.21 and SN 6.1 (see, e.g., Bodhi, 2000, pp. 233, 430, ''n''. 362; and Thanissaro, 1997). It is worthwhile noting as well that several other references in the Pali Canon to the Buddha's acting out of "compassion" are not related directly to ''karuṇā'' but to the synonymous ''anukampā'' (which is also defined as "mercy" in Rhys Davids & Stede, 1921-25, p. 34). ===Mahayana Buddhism=== In Mahāyāna Buddhism, karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is one of the two qualities, along with enlightened wisdom ([[Sanskrit]]: ''[[prajña]]''), to be cultivated on the [[bodhisattva]] path. According to scholar [[Rupert Gethin]], this elevation of karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā to the status of [[prajña]] is one of the distinguishing factors between the Theravāda [[arahant]] ideal and the Mahāyāna bodhisattva ideal: {{quote|For the Mahāyāna ... the path to arhatship appears tainted with a residual selfishness since it lacks the motivation of the great compassion (''mahākaru{{IAST|ṇ}}ā'') of the bodhisattva, and ultimately the only legitimate way of Buddhist practice is the bodhisattva path.Gethin (1999), p. 228.}} Throughout the Mahāyāna world, [[Avalokiteśvara]] (Sanskrit; Chinese: [[Guan Yin]]; Japanese: [[Kannon]]; Tibetan: Chenrezig) is a bodhisattva who embodies karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā. In the Intermediate section of the ''Stages of Meditation'' by [[Kamalaśīla]], he writes: {{quote|Moved by compassion[karunā], Bodhisattvas take the vow to liberate all sentient beings. Then by overcoming their self-centered outlook, they engage eagerly and continuously in the very difficult practices of accumulating merit and insight. Having entered into this practice, they will certainly complete the collection of merit and insight. Accomplishing the accumulation of merit and insight is like having omniscience itself in the palm of your hand. Therefore, since compassion is the only root of omniscience, you should become familiar with this practice from the very beginning."''Stages of Meditation'' by H.H The Dalai Lama, Root Text by Kamalashila. Snow Lion Publications. Page 42-43}} In [[Tibetan Buddhism]], one of the foremost authoritative texts on the Bodhisattva path is the ''[[Bodhisattvacaryāvatāra]]'' by Shantideva. In the eighth section entitled ''Meditative Concentration'', Shantideva describes meditation on Karunā as thus: {{quote|Strive at first to meditate upon the sameness of yourself and others. In joy and sorrow all are equal; Thus be guardian of all, as of yourself. The hand and other limbs are many and distinct, But all are one--the body to kept and guarded. Likewise, different beings, in their joys and sorrows, are, like me, all one in wanting happiness. This pain of mine does not afflict or cause discomfort to another's body, and yet this pain is hard for me to bear because I cling and take it for my own. And other beings' pain I do not feel, and yet, because I take them for myself, their suffering is mine and therefore hard to bear. And therefore I'll dispel the pain of others, for it is simply pain, just like my own. And others I will aid and benefit, for they are living beings, like my body. Since I and other beings both, in wanting happiness, are equal and alike, what difference is there to distinguish us, that I should strive to have my bliss alone?"''The Way of the Bodhisattva'' by Shantideva. Shambhala Publications. Page 122-123}} ==Jainism== Karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is associated with the Jain practice of compassion. For instance, karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is one of the four reflections of universal friendship — along with amity (Sanskrit: ''[[Mettā|maitri]]''), appreciation (''pramoda'') and equanimity (''madhyastha'')—used to stop (''[[samvara]]'') the influx of [[Karma in Jainism|karma]].[http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~pluralsm/affiliates/jainism/jainedu/9tattva.htm Shah (n.d.).] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090605003634/http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~pluralsm/affiliates/jainism/jainedu/9tattva.htm |date=2009-06-05 }} Regarding ''samvara'', see [[Karma_in_Jainism#Release_from_karmas|"Release from karmas"]]. From a comparative religion perspective, cf. Buddhism's four [[brahmavihara]]; for instance, ''maitri'' is often identified as a Sanskrit correlate of the Pali ''mettā'' (Rhys Davids & Stede, 1921-5, p. 540, entry for "Mettā," retrieved at http://dsal.uchicago.edu/cgi-bin/philologic/getobject.pl?c.3:1:177.pali{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}). ==Miscellaneous== Karu{{IAST|ṇ}}ā is a common first name throughout [[India]], used for both genders. Lithuanian "karūna" means "crown", possible relation of meaning of qualities of crown owners. ==See also== * [[Bodhicitta]] * [[Bodhisattva]] * [[Brahmavihara]] * [[Life release]] * [[Nīlakantha dhāranī]] * [[Metta]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * [[Bhikkhu Bodhi]] (trans.) {{About|the Dutch educator, Quaker missionary and pacifist|the Dutch musician|Kees Boeke (musician)}} [[File:Kees Boeke (1939).jpg|right|thumb]] '''Cornelis Boeke''' (25 September 1884, [[Alkmaar]] – 3 July 1966, [[Abcoude]]), usually known as '''Kees Boeke''', was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] reformist [[educator]], [[Quaker]] [[missionary]] and [[pacifist]]. He is best known for his popular essay/book ''[[Cosmic View]]'' (1957) which presents a seminal view of the universe, from the galactic to the microscopic scale, and which inspired several films.
Boeke tried to reform education by allowing the children to contribute their ideas. He called this process [[sociocracy]] and regarded schools as workshops, with pupils as workers, and teachers as co-workers. Based on [[Religious Society of Friends|Quaker]] ideas, he wanted the children to respect [[democracy]]. In 1926, he founded a school in [[Bilthoven]], which he led until 1954. As a child, the later Dutch [[Queen Beatrix]] attended the school.
==Biography== Kees Boeke grew up in a [[Mennonite]] family in Alkmaar. He studied [[architecture]] at the [[Delft University of Technology]]. As a student, he spent a year in [[England]], where he met the Quakers. He became a Quaker and attended [[Woodbrooke Quaker Study Centre]], a college in [[Selly Oak]], [[Birmingham]]. There, he found inspiration in [[Bournville]], the garden village which the [[Cadbury]] family (owners of the chocolate factory) had built for their workers. He met and married Beatrice (Betty) Cadbury. The couple went to [[Syria]] in 1912 as Quaker missionaries. In 1914, after the outbreak of [[World War I]], they returned to England. They became active in peace work, the [[Fellowship of Reconciliation]] having come into being in 1914 through [[Henry Hodgkin]]. In 1915 Boeke traveled to [[Berlin]], where he met [[Friedrich Siegmund-Schultze]], with whom Hodgkin had been working at the outbreak of war. Boeke began to speak publicly in England: "The Germans are our brothers; God did not create man that he might kill; the war will find its quickest end when all soldiers lay down their weapons." He was deported from [[United Kingdom|Britain]] and returned to the Netherlands. His family followed; there they lived in Bilthoven, near [[Utrecht]]. Their home soon became a pacifist centre. Later in the Second World War Boeke took part in the underground Dutch resistance movement against the same Germans, he called brothers before. This was, however, in line with his ideas of anti-authority and his disapproval of war and prosecution.
After the First World War, Boeke erected a large conference centre in Bilthoven, which he called "Brotherhood House." The first international peace conference took place there between 4 and 11 October 1919. Present at the conference were [[Leon Revoyne]], [[Mathilda Wrede]], [[Leonard Ragaz]], [[Pierre Ceresole]], as well as Hodgkin and Schultze. Boeke and Ceresole became the secretaries of this movement, which initially called itself "Christian International", later the [[International Fellowship of Reconciliation]]. Together with [[Helene Stöcker]], and [[Wilfred Wellock]], they founded the [[Service Civil International]] and in 1921 "Paco" (the [[Esperanto]] word for peace), which in 1923 became [[War Resisters' International]] (WRI).
Kees and Betty Boeke considered war to be rooted in the entanglement of the [[State (polity)|state]] and [[capitalism]]. As Betty was a Cadbury, she inherited large shares in her family's firm. She transferred this money to various charitable organizations such as the Quaker-Help Organisation in Russia in 1920. Later, she gave the shares to a trust for the workers of the Cadbury factory. For a while, the Boekes abstained from using money, so as to avoid contributing to the state — since public funds are also spent on weapons. They never used public transport, nor did they pay postage, tolls, or taxes. As a result, they were imprisoned several times. On one occasion the Dutch tax authorities auctioned off the estate in order to recover taxes. [[Wilhelmina of the Netherlands|Queen Wilhelmina]] was in attendance at the auction, and purchased Kees' favorite violin, only to return it to him on the spot. Boeke supported his family by working in Utrecht in a building association which he had founded; he did not work as an architect (which was his training), but as a simple worker.
In the late 1920s Boeke increasingly withdrew from international peace movements. Believing he could build a better society through educating children, he started a school called "De werkplaats" (the workshop). He founded his school in 1926 when all private schools, including the [[Montessori school]] his children attended, started receiving an equal amount of money per child from the state, to which he objected. [[File:Kees Boeke (1946).jpg|thumb|Kees Boeke with [[Beatrix of the Netherlands]] (right) in 1946]] His school, which uses [[Montessori method|Maria Montessori's methods]], extended by Boeke's own educational ideas, became nationally known; even the Dutch queen Juliana sent her daughters there.<ref>[http://geschiedenis.vpro.nl/programmas/2899536/afleveringen/40041487/ (Dutch) De school van Beatrix.] [[Andere Tijden]], 25 september 2008</ref> The school has been hugely influential for its creative way of making the students co-responsible for their own curriculum, together with the teachers; many students who failed in regular schools have blossomed at "De werkplaats", but on the other hand many talented children could not reach a high level in this school.
Co-responsibility in school did not mean a freewheeling life at "the Werkplaats". Children had to perform tasks such as cleaning the school, growing vegetables and fruits, and helping with lunch cooking. Boeke's notion of sociocracy was, in effect, a secular implementation of the Quaker ideals applied to education in such a way that children were treated as adults, and were on first-name terms with their teachers.
Boeke wrote a major book on education[what is its title, etc.?!]. One of his last works was [[Cosmic View]] (New York 1957). He died in 1966 in the company of his family.
==Legacy== Boeke's system of [[sociocracy]] survives today and was expanded upon in the work of a well-known student of the school, Dr. [[Gerard Endenburg]], who in the 1960s and '70s developed a governance and decision-making methodology by the same name while directing the [[Endenburg Electrotechniek]] company.
Boeke's essay/book [[Cosmic View]] (1957) presents a seminal view of the universe, from the galactic to the microscopic scale. It inspired several films:
* ''[[Cosmic Zoom]]'' (1968) produced by the [[National Film Board of Canada]] * ''[[Powers of Ten (film)|Powers of Ten]]'' (1968; new version in 1977) by [[Charles and Ray Eames]] * The [[IMAX]] film ''[[Cosmic Voyage]]'' (1996) produced for the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[National Air and Space Museum]]. * "Superpowers of Ten" (2013), a theater piece produced by [[Andrés Jaque]] and performed at the Lisbon Triennial, the Chicago Architectural Biennial, [[Museo Jumex]] in Mexico and [[ZKM]] in Karlsruhe ''Cosmic View'' is mentioned as an inspiration by [[Will Wright (game designer)|Will Wright]], creator of a [[video game]], ''[[Spore (2008 video game)|Spore]]'' (2008).<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2008/sep/14/games Cosmic view, inspiration for a video game.] The Guardian, 14 September 2008</ref>

Maldum | image = Kjell Olav Maldum panter.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Kjell Olav Amdam Maldum | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|12|07}} | birth_place = [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | residence = [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | nationality = Norwegian | alma_mater = [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology|NTNU]] | title = [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] and [[Chairman]] of [[Infinitum AS]] | years_active = 1980–present | net_worth = | boards = [http://www.Loop.no Loop], [[Infinitum AS|Infinitum]], DMF, [[Green Dot (symbol)|Green Dot]] | children = | parents = | website = | signature = | signature_alt = | spouse = }} '''Kjell Olav A. Maldum''' (born 12 December 1962) is a Norwegian entrepreneur and business leader. He is a public figure{{cite web|title= Going for recycling (English-translated title) |url=http://hmsmagasinet.no/g%C3%A5r-gjenvinning|accessdate=7 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Sørheim|first1=Tone Iren|title=Fallende oljepris kan gjøre panteflaskene mindre lønnsomme|url=http://e24.no/naeringsliv/fallende-oljepris-kan-gjoere-panteflaskene-mindre-loennsomme/23429941|accessdate=7 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Not in the box!|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/amagasinet/Ikke-i-boks-256945b.html|accessdate=7 September 2016}} in the Norwegian movement for bottle recycling, an equivalent to [[bottle bill]] in the US and [[Container deposit legislation in Australia|cash for container]] in Australia. Since 2007, he has been serving as the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] and [[Chairman]] of [[Infinitum AS]], the operator of the national paid recycling scheme for bottles and cans marked with the official "recyclable" or "[[Container deposit legislation|deposit]]" logo in Norway.{{cite web|title=Arguing about bottle deposit money (English-translated title)|url=http://www.tu.no/artikler/krangler-om-pantepenger/241926|accessdate=2 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Better sorting, better price (English-translated title)|url=http://www.tu.no/artikler/industri-jo-bedre-sortering-jo-bedre-pris/248784|accessdate=2 September 2016}} ==Early career== Being a graduated from [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology|NTNU]] in [[Trondheim]], Maldum has served in different technical and leadership positions before being appointed as [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of Infinitum in 2007. He has been a Department Manager at [[National Institute of Technology (Norway)]] Teknologisk Institutt 1990-2000, and CEO of Groceries' Environmental Forum or DMF (DAGLIGVAREHANDELENS MILJØFORUM in Norwegian) 2001–2007{{cite web|title=Going for recycling (English-translated title)|url=http://hmsmagasinet.no/g%C3%A5r-gjenvinning|website=HMSmagasinet.no|accessdate=2 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Sørheim|first1=Tone Iren|title=Falling oil price may make deposit bottles less profitable (English-translated title))|url=http://e24.no/naeringsliv/fallende-oljepris-kan-gjoere-panteflaskene-mindre-loennsomme/23429941|accessdate=2 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Eikernytt.no|url=http://www.eikernytt.no/nyhet.cfm?nyhetid=4839|website=www.eikernytt.no|accessdate=2 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Forum for fossil plastics strikes a blow for recyclable plastic as a good alternative (English-translated title)|url=http://packnews.no/default.asp?id=8646&show=more|website=packnews.no|accessdate=2 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=English Dagligvarehandelens miljøforum|url=http://www.etos.no/english/|website=www.etos.no|accessdate=7 September 2016}} ==Advocating for environment== Through his career and especially in deposit-return system for bottles, he became a known figure for advocating for environment in Norway, lecturing at academic gatherings {{cite web|title=Logistics Seminar in Bergen, February 2007|url=http://www.logistikkforeningen.no/file.php?id=271|website=Logistikkforeningen.no|accessdate=5 September 2016}} and national TV programs to promote the idea of {{cite web|title=NRK TV - Søk - Kjell Olav Maldum|url=https://tv.nrk.no/sok?q=Kjell%20Olav%20Maldum&filter=rettigheter|website=NRK TV|accessdate=5 September 2016}} where he has promoted sustainable production with low impact on environment and recycling of one-way containers{{cite web|title=Vil heve panten på boks og flasker|url=https://www.nrk.no/rogaland/vil-heve-panten-pa-boks-og-flasker-1.7307823|accessdate=5 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=NRK TV 16.09.2011 (program nr 1435)|url=https://www.nrk.no/kultur/16.09.2011-_program-nr-1435_-1.7794618|accessdate=5 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Mangler 40 millioner bokser|url=https://www.nrk.no/norge/mangler-40-millioner-bokser-1.5507016|accessdate=5 September 2016}} and avoid wasting food.{{cite web|title=Right in the garbage with fruit and vegetables (English-translated title)|url=http://www.vg.no/forbruker/mat-og-drikke/mat/rett-i-soepla-med-frukt-og-groent/a/105074/|accessdate=5 September 2016}}
In 2006 he won the Optimization Award of the year in Norway.{{cite web|title=Optimization Award 2006: the winner is Kjell Olav Maldum - Ny Teknikk|url=http://www.nyteknikk.no/index.php?articleid=2570|website=www.nyteknikk.no|accessdate=2 September 2016}} It has been the first time that a person won the award instead of an entity for "his extensive efforts to ensure that the retail sector have optimal logistics and thus be the most environmentally friendly{{cite web|title=Emballasjedagene 07: Kjell Olav Maldum fikk Optimeringsprisen {{!}} PACKobserver|url=http://www.packobserver.dk/idn651.asp|accessdate=7 September 2016}}
Maldum has been behind the deposit-return TV commercials and "Infinitum movement"{{cite web|title=Infinitum Movement|url=http://infinitummovement.no/|website=Infinitum Movement|accessdate=7 September 2016}} in Norway where a number of celebrities, artists and athletes advertise and encourage for recycling of the materials in the society. The movememnt encourages people to infinitely recycle instead the containers instead of just rhewoing them away. Prime Minister [[Erna Solberg]] also took part{{cite web|title=NRK TV - Se Dagsrevyen 21|url=https://tv.nrk.no/serie/dagsrevyen-21/NNFA21101614/16-10-2014|website=National Norwegian TV - NRK|accessdate=7 September 2016}}{{cite web|title=Statsministeren gir sin pant til TV-aksjonen|url=http://infinitum.no/aktuelt/statsministeren-gir-sin-pant-til-tv-aksjonen|website=infinitum.no|accessdate=7 September 2016}} in the TV action for the bottle recycling. ==Special initiatives== *Coca-Cola switching to deposit bottles Until 2014 [[Coca-Cola]] has been using non-deposit bottle for its beverages in Norway. Kjell Olav Maldum played a central role in negotiations for Coca-Cola Norway switching from non-deposit refillable bottles to non-refillable deposit bottles. The move was considered as an environmentally friendly one to introduce deposit on bottles and decrease littering, but it also led to downsizing of Coca-Cola in Norway due to less labor needed for one-way bottles and made headline in Norwegian market about the job losses and also counter-arguments {{cite web|title=Cola-kutt kan gi nye arbeidsplasser|url=https://www.nrk.no/ostlandssendingen/cola-kutt-kan-gi-nye-arbeidsplasser-1.7991853|accessdate=5 September 2016}} Coca-Cola Norway also promised to invest in recycling facilities inside Norway.{{cite web|title=Packaging: Recycling|url=http://www.coca-colacompany.com/stories/packaging-recycling|accessdate=5 September 2016}} *Recycling cans in Norway Maldum was also behind the efforts that finally led to the recycling of aluminum cans performed in Norway. The aluminum cans that have been collected in Norway were used to be sent to France for recycling but it has been recycled by Norsk Hydro in Holmestrand since 2014.{{cite web|last1=Solholm|first1=Rolleiv|title=More environmentally friendly recycling|url=http://www.norwaypost.no/index.php/culture/museums/29252|website=www.norwaypost.no|accessdate=5 September 2016}} The move was considered as environmentally friendly step vowing for recycling 60,000 mt of aluminium annually in Holmestrand.{{cite web|title=Now recycled in Norway: drink cans get a shorter trip to their new life - Norsk Hydro|url=http://www.hydro.com/en/Press-room/News/Archive/2013/Now-recycled-in-Norway-drink-cans-get-a-shorter-trip-to-their-new-life-/|website=www.hydro.com|accessdate=5 September 2016}} ==See also== [[Infinitum AS]] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maldum, Kjell Olav A.}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Recycling industry]] [[Category:Waste legislation]] [[Category:Recycling]] [[Category:Containers]]

A '''Mani Jewel''' ({{CJKV|c=摩尼珠|p=móní zhū|j=mani ju}}) refers to any of various jewels mentioned in [[Buddhist]] literature as either metaphors for several concepts in [[Buddhist philosophy]] or as mythical [[relic]]s. The word ''mani'' is simply [[Sanskrit]] and [[Pali]] for "jewel", so the phrase "Mani Jewel" is in one sense redundant. However, the Mani Jewel metaphors were significantly expanded in Chinese language texts in which it was also called by essentially the same redundant name ''móní zhū'', where the first two characters (摩尼, móní) are the [[Orthographic transcription|transcription]] of ''mani'' and the third character (珠) is its Chinese translation, "jewel". The English phrase "Mani Jewel" is thus in essence a translation of the Chinese term. The use of the Mani Jewel in Buddhist literature includes various magical relics such as the wish-fulfilling [[cintamani]] as well as metaphorical devices to illustrate several ideas such as [[Buddha-nature]] and [[Śūnyatā]]. ==Early Literary References== The Mani Jewel makes its first appearance in the [[Pali]] [[Nikāya]]s where it is mentioned as one of the seven treasures owned by a "wheel-turning king". The Mahasudhassana Sutta in the [[Digha Nikaya]] describes the Mani Jewel as follows:
“It was a beryl, pure, excellent, well-cut into eight facets, clear, bright, unflawed, perfect in every respect. The luster of this Jewel-Treasure radiated for an entire yojana round about.
The Mani Jewel in this text serves as the source of virtue and good governance for the king. Without it he would lose his throne. Later texts describe the Mani Jewel differently. One version is the [[Cintamani]] or wish-fulfilling jewel. It was said to be originally owned by the God [[Indra]], but it fell to the earth during a war with the [[Asura]]s, allowing whoever possess it to have their wishes granted. Depictions of the [[Bodhisattva]]s [[Ksitigarbha]] and [[Avalokiteshvara]] sometimes show them holding this Cintamani, indicating their ability to fulfill the wishes of sentient beings. The Mani Jewel also appears as a water purifying jewel (清水摩尼) where it could be placed in muddy water by traveling monks, causing any cloudiness to settle out leaving the water clear and pure. This version of the jewel is mentioned in the [[Abhidharma-kosa]] where it is used as a metaphor for faith as an agent capable of dispelling uncertainty. Yet another depiction of the jewel is in the metaphor of [[Indra's net]] which appears in the [[Avatamsaka Sutra]]. It describes a net of infinite size with infinite knots, with each knot containing a Mani Jewel with infinite facets. Each individual Mani Jewel reflects every other Mani Jewel in the same way that any individual being or [[phenomenon]] is indistinguishable from the whole or [[noumenon]] due to their fundamental [[Pratītyasamutpāda|interconnectedness]]. ==In Buddha Nature Sutras== The [[Lankavatara Sutra]], the [[Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment]], and the [[Surangama Sutra]] all used the Mani Jewel as metaphors for [[Buddha-nature]]. In these sutras, a transparent Mani Jewel within us changes colors depending on the conditions around us, representing the [[Skandha|five skandhas]]. The Mani Jewel itself represents each being's Buddha-nature, but because of the [[Three poisons (Buddhism)|three poisons]] of ignorance, attachment, and aversion, a being sees only the various colors emitted by the jewel. These are mistakenly perceived as the defilements rather than the purity of the jewel itself, which is merely reflecting conditions around it. Thus Buddha-nature is not perceived and only the five skandhas are seen, which are then conflated with a sense of self in opposition to the Buddhist idea of [[Anatta|anātman]] or no-self. ==In Zen== Later, the Mani Jewel began to appear in texts produced by Zen Buddhists. An early example is found in [[Guifeng Zongmi]]'s work ''Chart of the Master-Disciple Succession of the Chan Gate That Transmits the Mind Ground in China'' in which he compares the four contemporary Zen schools: the Northern School, the Ox Head School, the [[Hongzhou school]] and the [[Heze school]]. He accomplishes this by comparing how each school would interpret the Mani Jewel metaphor used in the Sutra of Perfect Enlightenment discussed above. According to Guifeng, the Northern School would believe in a fundamentally pure Mani Jewel that must be cleaned to reveal its purity; the Ox Head school would perceive both the color reflections and the Mani Jewel itself as [[Shunyata|empty]]; the Hongzhou school would say that the blackness covering the Mani Jewel is the Jewel itself, and that its purity can never be seen; the Heze School (to which Guifeng belonged) would interpret the black color covering the jewel as an illusion that is in fact just a manifestation of its brightness such that the surface defilements and the purity of the Jewel interpenetrate one another.{{citation|last=Okumura|first=Shohaku|journal=Dharma Eye|pages=12–20|date=March 2015|number=35|month=|title=The 7th Chapter of Shobogenzo Ikka-myoju (One Bright Jewel): Lecture 1|url=http://global.sotozen-net.or.jp/eng/dharma/pdf/35e.pdf}} [[Eihei Dōgen]], a 13th-century Zen monk and founder of the [[Sōtō school]] of Zen Buddhism in Japan, wrote extensively on the Mani Jewel in an essay of his large work the [[Shōbōgenzō]] entitled ''[[Ikka myōju]]'', or ''One Bright Jewel''. The essay primarily comments on the phrase of the [[Tang Dynasty]] Chinese monk [[Xuansha Shibei]], who wrote that "the ten-direction world is one bright jewel". His phrase is in turn an adaptation of the earlier writings of Guifeng Zongmi mentioned above. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Buddhism topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mani Jewel}} [[Category:Buddhist philosophical concepts]] [[Category:Buddhist terminology]]

A '''maxim''' is a concise expression of a fundamental [[morality|moral]] rule or principle, whether considered as [[wikt:objectivity|objective]] or [[subjectivity|subjective]] contingent on one's [[philosophy]]. A maxim is often [[pedagogy|pedagogical]] and motivates specific actions. The ''[[Oxford Dictionary of Philosophy]]'' defines it as: {{quote|Generally any simple and memorable rule or guide for living; for example, 'neither a borrower nor a lender be'. [[Alfred, Lord Tennyson|Tennyson]] speaks of 'a little hoard of maxims preaching down a daughter's heart ([[Locksley Hall]]), and maxims have generally been associated with a 'folksy' or 'copy-book' approach to [[moral]]ity.Oxford Dictionary of Philosophy, Maxim (Oxford University Press 2008) p. 226}} ==Deontological ethics== In [[deontological ethics]], mainly in [[Kantian ethics]], maxims are understood as [[subjectivity|subjective]] principles of action. A maxim is thought to be part of an agent's thought process for every rational action, indicating in its standard form: (1) the action, or type of action; (2) the conditions under which it is to be done; and (3) the end or purpose to be achieved by the action, or the motive. The maxim of an action is often referred to as the agent's intention. In Kantian ethics, the [[categorical imperative]] provides a test on maxims for determining whether the actions they refer to are right, wrong, or permissible. The categorical imperative is stated canonically as: "Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become a universal law."{{cite book |last=Kant|first=Immanuel|authorlink=Immanuel Kant |translator=James W. Ellington |title=Grounding for the Metaphysics of Morals 3rd ed.|publisher=Hackett|date=1993|pages=30|isbn=0-87220-166-X}} In his ''[[Critique of Practical Reason]]'', [[Immanuel Kant]] provided the following example of a maxim and of how to apply the test of the categorical imperative:
I have, for example, made it my maxim to increase my wealth by any safe means. Now I have a deposit in my hands, the owner of which has died and left no record of it. . . . I therefore apply the maxim to the present case and ask whether it could indeed take the form of a law, and consequently whether I could through my maxim at the same time give such a law as this: that everyone may deny a deposit which no one can prove has been made. I at once become aware that such a principle, as a law, would annihilate itself since it would bring it about that there would be no deposits at all.{{cite book |last=Kant|first=Immanuel|authorlink=Immanuel Kant|translator=Mary Gregor |title=Critique of Practical Reason|publisher=Cambridge University Press|date=1997|pages=25/5:27|isbn=0-521-59051-5}}
Also, an action is said to have "moral worth" if the maxim upon which the agent acts cites the purpose of conforming to a moral requirement. That is, a person's action has moral worth when he does his [[duty]] purely for the sake of duty, or does the right thing for the right reason. Kant himself believed that it is impossible to know whether anyone's action has ever had moral worth. It might appear to someone that he has acted entirely "from duty", but this could always be an illusion of self-interest: of wanting to see oneself in the best, most noble light. This indicates that agents are not always the best judges of their own maxims or motives. ==Personal knowledge== [[Michael Polanyi]] in his account of [[tacit knowledge]] stressed the importance of the maxim in focusing both explicit and implicit modes of understanding. “Maxims are rules, the correct application of which is part of the art they govern....Maxims can only function within a framework of personal (i.e., experiential) knowledge”.Quoted in Guy Claxton, ''Live and learn (1992) p. 116 == See also == {{Portal|Philosophy}} * [[Adage]] * [[Aphorism]] * [[Brocard (law)|Brocard]] * [[Ethics]] * [[Legal maxim]] * [[Morality]] * [[Paremiology]] * [[Principle]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080415174847/http://rpo.library.utoronto.ca/poem/2161.html Locksley Hall - Alfred Lord Tennyson] * [http://www.gutenberg.org/browse/authors/k#a1426 Online works of Immanuel Kant at Gutenberg] * [http://myweb.ecu.edu/mccartyr/GW/MaximsOfAction.asp Maxims of Action] {{DEFAULTSORT:Maxim (Philosophy)}} [[Category:Concepts in ethics]] [[Category:Kantianism]] [[Category:Statements]]

{{Unreferenced|date=September 2007}} '''Multilineal evolution''' is a 20th-century [[social theory]] about the [[evolution of societies]] and [[culture]]s. It is composed of many competing theories by various sociologists and anthropologists. This theory has replaced the older 19th century set of theories of [[unilineal evolution]].
When critique of classical social evolutionism became widely accepted, modern anthropological and sociological approaches have changed to reflect their responses to the critique of their predecessor. Modern theories are careful to avoid unsourced, ethnocentric speculation, comparisons, or value judgements; more or less regarding individual societies as existing within their own historical contexts. These conditions provided the context for new theories such as [[cultural relativism]] and multilineal evolution.
By the 1940s cultural anthropologists such as [[Leslie White]] and [[Julian Steward]] sought to revive an evolutionary model on a more scientific basis, and succeeded in establishing an approach known as the [[neoevolutionism]]. White rejected the opposition between "primitive" and "modern" societies but did argue that societies could be distinguished based on the amount of energy they harnessed, and that increased energy allowed for greater social differentiation. Steward on the other hand rejected the 19th century notion of progress, and instead called attention to the Darwinian notion of "adaptation", arguing that all societies had to adapt to their environment in some way.
The anthropologists [[Marshall Sahlins]] and [[Elman Service]] wrote a book, ''Evolution and Culture'', in which they attempted to synthesize White's and Steward's approaches. Other anthropologists, building on or responding to work by White and Steward, developed theories of cultural ecology and ecological anthropology. The most prominent examples are [[Peter Vayda]] and [[Roy Rappaport]]. By the late 1950s, students of Steward such as [[Eric Wolf]] and [[Sidney Mintz]] turned away from cultural ecology to [[Marxism]], [[World Systems Theory]], [[Dependency theory]] and [[Marvin Harris]]'s [[Cultural materialism (anthropology)|cultural materialism]].
Today most anthropologists continue to reject 19th century notions of progress and the three original assumptions of unilineal evolution. Following Steward, they take seriously the relationship between a culture and its environment in attempts to explain different aspects of a culture. But most modern cultural anthropologists have adopted a general systems approach, examining cultures as emergent systems and argue that one must consider the whole social environment, which includes political and economic relations among cultures. There are still others who continue to reject the entirety of the evolutionary thinking and look instead at historical contingencies, contacts with other cultures, and the operation of cultural symbol systems. As a result, the simplistic notion of 'cultural evolution' has grown less useful and given way to an entire series of more nuanced approaches to the relationship of culture and environment. In the area of development studies, authors such as [[Amartya Sen]] have developed an understanding of 'development' and 'human flourishing' that also question more simplistic notions of progress, while retaining much of their original inspiration.
==See also== * [[Neoevolutionism]] * [[Sociobiology]] * [[Theory of modernisation]] * [[Theory of post-industrial society]]
[[Category:Sociocultural evolution theory]] [[Category:Emergence]]

{{distinguish|Na Ree|Nari (disambiguation){{!}}Nari}} {{Infobox book | name = Naree
নারী | image = The cover of the book Naree by Humayun Azad.png | image_size = 220px | caption = The cover of the book third edition | alt = | author = [[Humayun Azad]] | title_orig = নারী | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = Uttam Sen | country = [[Bangladesh]] | language = [[Bengali language|Bengali]] | series = | subject = [[Woman]] | genre = Criticism | publisher = [[Agamee Prakashani]], [[Dhaka]] | publisher2 = | pub_date = [[1992 in literature|1992]] | english_pub_date = | media_type = Print ([[hardcover]]) | pages = 408 ''(third edition)'' | awards = | isbn = 978-984-04-0077-5 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | preceded_by_quotation_marks = | followed_by = | followed_by_quotation_marks = | wikisource = }} '''''Naree''''' ({{lang-en|Woman}}) is a 1992 Bangladeshi book about feminism and [[women’s rights]] written by [[Humayun Azad]].{{cite web |url=http://www.amarboi.com/2011/11/nari-humayun-azad-pdf.html |script-title=নারী - হুমায়ূন আজাদ |publisher=amarboi.com |language=bn |date= |accessdate=2013-06-21}}{{bn}} The book was considered incendiary, and was banned on 19 November 1995, by the [[government of Bangladesh]]. Five years later, though, in 2000, the ban was lifted, following a legal battle that Azad won.{{cite web |url=http://www.mukto-mona.com/link/book.htm |title=Recommended Books |publisher=Mukto-Mona |date= |accessdate=2013-06-21}} The [[High Court of Bangladesh]] decided that the prohibition was invalid.{{cite web |url=http://www.banned-books.info/book-content.php?key=90&time=1363397449 |title=Banned-books info. |publisher=banned-books.info |date= |accessdate=2013-06-21}} == Summary == The book in Bengali is a feminist analysis of women's status and condition in civilizations created by men. This is the first comprehensive discussion in Bengali about feminism and the difficulties Bengali women face in daily life. The [[Political radicalism|radicalism]] inherent in the work was enough for many to think back on ''[[The Second Sex]]'' written by French feminist [[Simone de Beauvoir]] and ''[[Sexual Politics]]'' by American feminist [[Kate Millett]]. In the work, Azad takes readers on a journey through the broad swathes of experience feminist writers in [[South Asia]] have gone through in their writings. Azad is critical of acclaimed figures, notably [[Rabindranath Tagore]] and [[Kazi Nazrul Islam]], for what he considers their anti-feminist perceptions of life.{{cite news |last=Ahsan |first=Syed Badrul |date=2 March 2013 |title=Words that have made a difference |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=270984 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=2013-06-21}} Azad analytically compiles the feminist ideas of the west, which underlie the feminist contributions of the subcontinent's socio-political reformers. == See also == * [[List of books banned by governments]] * [[Blasphemy law in Bangladesh]] * [[Women in Bangladesh]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== [[Category:1992 books]] [[Category:Bangladeshi books]] [[Category:Criticism]] [[Category:Essay collections]] [[Category:Feminist books]] [[Category:Humayun Azad]] [[Category:Books by Humayun Azad]] [[Category:Bangladeshi non-fiction books]] [[Category:Censored books]]
